Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Situation2: They are approached by someone struggling with personal or family issues and need to provide consistent guidance and encouragement.
Story:
The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my taxi crawling along the icy road. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch and muttering about missing his international flight. I could feel his anxiety pressing on me, the unspoken demand to get him to the airport on time despite the treacherous conditions. My duty as a driver was clear: keep him safe, but also get him there as quickly as possible.

My phone buzzed on the dashboard. It was a message from Maria, a member of my congregation. Her words were desperate—her marriage was falling apart, and she needed to talk to me right away. As her pastor, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to offer comfort and guidance. But I was stuck in this cab, responsible for the man in my back seat, the storm outside, and the clock ticking down to his departure.

I felt torn in two, the weight of both roles pressing on my chest. I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both needed me now. My hands tightened on the wheel as I tried to figure out what to do next.
